article.headline: Gonzaga 84, Idaho 63
article.story: SPOKANE, Wash. (AP) -- Blake Stepp proved he doesn't have to score many points for the Bulldogs to win. Stepp was held to 11 points, but had 13 assists and didn't commit a turnover in 35 minutes of play in No. 16 Gonzaga's 84-63 victory over Idaho on Friday night. "That's the best line by a point guard we've had around here in a long time," Coach Mark Few said. "He had a phenomenal game." Gonzaga (1-1) struggled early against the Vandals, who stayed within 10 points for most of the first 30 minutes. But an 18-0 run midway through the second half, when Gonzaga kept Idaho (1-2) scoreless for seven minutes, broke open the game. Cory Violette had two dunks and a 3-pointer and freshman Adam Morrison added consecutive baskets to help Gonzaga built a 73-48 lead. Violette finished with 11 points and five rebounds, while Morrison scored 10. Six Bulldogs scored as least nine points, led by Ronny Turiaf's 18. Tony Skinner had 10 and Kyle Bankhead nine. Stepp averaged 18 points per game last season, and Few set out to spread the scoring around to more players this season. The Bulldogs had trouble scoring in a 73-66 loss to Saint Joseph's in the season opener, but were more patient against Idaho. "They slowed it down and made the extra pass," Few said, after his team recorded 24 assists. Turiaf, who saw little playing time against Saint Joseph's because of an injured leg, added nine rebounds and four blocks in 30 minutes. "He's a warrior. That's why he's an NBA prospect," said Idaho's Tyrone Hayes, who led the Vandals with 20 points and seven rebounds. "I thought our big guys did a very good job on him but he got to the line." Turiaf made only four of 15 shots, but he was 10-of-14 from the line. Turiaf said a key was holding Idaho to 39-percent shooting, including four of 17 from 3-point range. "That's our identity this year. We have to be great on defense," Turiaf said. Idaho lost by 50 points the last time it played in The Kennel in 2000. "They're very difficult to guard," Idaho coach Leonard Perry said. "They spread you out. They're very physical inside. We fouled them a ton." Gonzaga is 56-3 at home the past five seasons, but will abandon The Kennel for a new home court next year. The schools have played 129 times since 1909, but this was their first meeting since 2000, when Gonzaga's 92-42 win prompted Idaho to cancel the next season's game for competitive reasons. Perry played against Gonzaga twice when he was a guard for the Vandals, winning in the 1989 and 1990 seasons. Idaho has not beaten Gonzaga since the 1997-98 season. Tanoris Shepard added 14 points for the Vandals.
